title: At least nine dead and thousands wounded as pagers explode across Lebanon
summary: According to Lebanon's health minister, nine people were killed and some 2,800 wounded on Tuesday. Hezbollah accused Israel of being responsible.

title: French Renaissance poet Joachim Du Bellay identified in coffin found at Notre-Dame
summary: The resolution of this cold case is the most spectacular aspect of the assessment of the archaeological excavations carried out under the cathedral and presented on Tuesday, September 17.

title: US Judge orders Sean 'Diddy' Combs to be jailed in sex trafficking and racketeering charges
summary: On Monday, a magistrate ordered the music mogul to be held without bail in a case that accuses him of presiding over a sordid empire of sexual crimes.

title: After prisoner exchange with the West, Russians keep writing to dissidents still in prison
summary: Sending letters to imprisoned dissidents is one of the last legal ways for Russians to show their opposition to the Kremlin and its 'special military operation' in Ukraine.

title: Radical left's impeachment effort against Macron passes first hurdle but is unlikely to succeed
summary: The bureau of the Assemblée Nationale validated the admissibility of the procedure initiated by the radical left on Tuesday. However, the highly complex process is unlikely to succeed.

title: Von der Leyen unveils new EU leadership team
summary: Key appointments include French candidate Stéphane Séjourné for industrial strategy, former Lithuanian prime minister Andrius Kubilius as defense commissioner and Spanish socialist Teresa Ribera overseeing climate policy.

title: North Korea fires multiple short-range ballistic missiles
summary: Pyongyang fired the missiles early Wednesday, Seoul's military said. Kim Jong Un's regime has staged dozens of launches this year, part of a testing spree that experts say could be linked to North Korea's alleged illicit supplying of weapons to ally Russia for use in Ukraine.

title: Lack of citizenship documents might keep many from voting in Arizona state and local races
summary: Nearly 100,000 voters who haven't submitted the documents might be prevented from participating in the elections. The announcement Tuesday of an error in state-run databases that reclassified voters comes days before county election officials are required to mail ballots to uniformed and overseas voters.

title: Georgia passes controversial bill restricting LGBTQ+ rights
summary: Georgia's parliament on Tuesday approved legislation that 'concerns restricting, in educational institutions and TV broadcasts, the propaganda of same-sex relationships and incest,' a measure that echoes laws adopted in neighboring Russia.

title: Storm Boris floods central Europe, causing major damage
summary: Severe rainfall is causing deadly flooding in several Central European countries.

title: 'I am a rapist like the others in this room', says main defendant in French mass rape trial
summary: Dominique Pelicot, who is being tried along with 50 other men for having raped his ex-wife and invited strangers to rape her while she was heavily sedated, is back in court on Tuesday after being excused for about a week for medical reasons.

title: Ryan Imperio's captivating image of Baily's beads wins astronomical photo of the year
summary: The American photographer was presented with the prize, awarded annually by the Royal Observatory at Greenwich, on September 12.

title: Stéphane Séjourné, from foreign minister to potential EU commissioner
summary: The Macron loyalist was confirmed as executive vice president in charge of industrial strategy in the next European Commission by Ursula von der Leyen on Tuesday. He spent only eight months at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

title: Thierry Breton's resignation marks the end of a stormy relationship with Ursula von der Leyen
summary: The European commissioner's repeated criticism of the Commission president eventually cost him his job. President Macron decided to appoint someone close to him in his place, the outgoing foreign affairs minister, Stéphane Séjourné.

title: Jean-Luc Mélenchon in leather and a rosette. Does anyone care?
summary: The day after Michel Barnier was appointed French prime minister on September 6, the leader of the radical-left party La France Insoumise led a march against 'Macron's power grab.'

title: Gunmen attack police base in Mali capital
summary: Bamako's airport was temporarily closed after gunmen attacked a military base in the capital on Tuesday. Mali's general staff later said that the attack killed a number of military personnel but did not give a detailed toll. An Al-Qaeda-linked group claimed responsibility.

title: Libya's reconstruction of Derna: 'A windfall for the Haftar clan'
summary: A year ago, the city was ravaged by deadly floods. Today, authorities in the east of the country have highlighted reconstruction that has been carried out, taking care not to detail the cost.

title: German tourist dies after losing leg in shark attack off Canary Islands
summary: The 30-year-old woman lost a leg in the attack and died of a heart attack while being transported in a Spanish rescue helicopter on Monday.

title: Starmer looks to Italy's far-right for 'solutions' on immigration
summary: The Labour prime minister, who visited Rome on Monday, praised several aspects of Giorgia Meloni's 'plan' to tackle immigration. For now, Starmer's border control strategy focuses on intensifying efforts against smugglers.

title: European Commission: Ursula von der Leyen presents a right-wing-dominated team
summary: The weakening of the French and German governments at home, and a College of Commissioners without a dominant figure, reinforces the German president's political clout.

title: For the UN, Venezuela's post-election crisis 'marked a new milestone in the deterioration of the rule of law'
summary: Since the presidential elections in Venezuela on July 28, the authorities have stepped up their repressive actions against the opposition, according to a recently published United Nations report.

title: In Hong Kong, a young man sentenced for wearing a 'Liberate Hong Kong' T-shirt
summary: Chu Kai-pong, 27, a victim of the new security law passed earlier this year under pressure from Beijing, faces up to seven years in prison.

title: California governor signs laws to crack down on election deepfakes created by AI
summary: The new bill, set to take effect immediately, makes it illegal to create and publish deepfakes related to elections 120 days before Election Day and 60 days thereafter. It also allows courts to stop distribution of the materials and impose civil penalties.

title: Movement for release of Israeli hostages joins anti-Netanyahu protests
summary: Large-scale demonstrations against the prime minister are unlikely to overshadow his popularity.

title: India's Modi exhibits poor record in the first 100 days of his third mandate
summary: The half-victory in the June elections of the prime minister's Bharatiya Janata Party reduced the head of government's room for maneuver, forcing him to form an alliance with unpredictable regional leaders.

title: The extremely vulnerable position France's PM finds himself in
summary: Michel Barnier must quickly build up his own legitimacy and avoid becoming dependent on a vengeful right-wing, writes Le Monde's political columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: Anarchy reigns in Sweida, Syria's main Druze city
summary: 'Syrian Diaries (4/7).' Abandoned by the central authorities, the city near the Jordanian border is plagued by racketeering, trafficking of all kinds and kidnappings.

title: Poland, Europe's new key player
summary: Threatened by Moscow, buoyed by its economic growth and disappointed by Berlin's attitude, Warsaw intends to play a major role within the EU 27, particularly on defense issues.

title: Three Iranian actresses forced into exile after starring in  'The Seed of the Sacred Fig,' which won at Cannes
summary: Niousha Akhshi, Mahsa Rostami and Setareh Maleki were forced to flee Iran, leaving their families behind after secretly acting in Mohammad Rasoulof's latest film, which won the Jury's Special Prize at Cannes. They now live in Berlin.

title: French mass rape trial: What exactly is 'chemical submission'?
summary: The use of drugs to perpetrate sexual assaults has been on the rise over the past 20 years, according to the National Agency for Medicine Safety (ANSM).

title: 'Zelensky hopes to get an invitation for Ukraine to join NATO out of Biden before he leaves the White House'
summary: The Ukrainian president, hoping to hasten the end of the war, seeks to persuade the US president to take decisive action and enable Kyiv to enter negotiations from a position of strength, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: In first court testimony, Dominique Pelicot says 50 men he invited to rape his wife 'knew everything'
summary: The main defendant in a French mass rape trial spoke on the stand for the first time on Tuesday, admitting to being a 'rapist, like the others in this room.'

title: Lebanon rocked by Hezbollah pager attack
summary: Nine people were killed in the explosions and some 2,800 were wounded, most of them Shiite fighters.

title: EU court annuls €1.49 billion fine against Google
summary: Google won a court challenge on Wednesday against a European Union antitrust fine imposed five years ago that targeted its online advertising business.

title: French PM says country's budgetary situation is 'very serious'
summary: Michel Barnier, who is to present a 2025 budget to parliament next month, said that the budgetary situation 'requires more than just pretty statements. It requires responsible action.'

title: EU foreign policy chief urges Georgia to retract bill restricting LGBTQ+ rights
summary: The EU has already warned Georgia's government that its membership bid has been 'de facto halted' as it advances a string of measures that run counter to European values.

title: Pager explosions targeting Hezbollah members injure thousands in Lebanon
summary: Hezbollah confirmed that beepers belonging to its members were detonated on Tuesday.

title: War in Ukraine exposes ambiguities of Swiss neutrality
summary: Ever since Russia's invasion in February 2022 unsettled Europe's security framework, Switzerland has questioned its own identity.

title: Mali's capital hit by first major jihadist attack since junta came to power
summary: The Jama'a Nusrat ul-Islam wa al-Muslimin claimed responsibility for attacks on a gendarmerie training center and parts of the Modibo Keita International Airport on Tuesday, September 17.

title: Hezbollah pager blasts most likely caused by inserted explosive
summary: Tuesday's attack left more than 2,800 people injured and at least 12 dead, mainly in Lebanon.

title: Taylor Swift's cat, a political figure in his own right
summary: The 34-year-old American pop star posed with her cat Benjamin Button on social media when she announced her support for Kamala Harris on September 10.

title: Dominique Pelicot copycat says he deserves to be punished
summary: Pelicot, 71, admitted slipping his then-wife Gisèle Pelicot sedatives to render her unconscious so that he and dozens of strangers could rape her for nearly a decade.

title: Two dead in botched takeover bid of Russian retailer's office
summary: Two security guards at Wildberries main Moscow office were shot dead on Wednesday after armed men accompanying the estranged husband of the CEO illegally entered the building and opened fire.
